FacilityName: City of Anderson, IN - Wheeler Ave Water Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Anderson is committed to minimizing the risk to employees and to the public of injury or death from an accidental release of chlorine. Chlorine gas is the only regulated substance at the Wheeler Avenue WTP and is used for disinfection of the City's water supply. The chlorine gas is dissolved in water (through a chlorinator) to form the disinfection agent, liquid chlorine. The maximum amount of chlorine in this process at any one time is 6,000 pounds. This represents two full one-ton cylinders being connected simultaneously, and one full one-ton cylinder in storage. This amount exceeds the threshold for EPA's Risk Management Planning of 2500 pounds. There are possible offsite consequences from a chlorine release, and this facility is covered by OSHA's process safety management standard. Therefore, the Wheeler Avenue WTP is subject to risk management program level 3.

The Wheeler Avenue WTP maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the chlorine process. These operating procedures are instrumental in ensuring safe operation of the systems and preventing accidental releases. An equipment failure could also result in an accidental release. The WTP has a maintenance program that is also critical to maintain the on-going mechanical integrity of the process equipment. The Plant Superintendent ensures that all chlorine process safety information is kept up-to-date, and maintained in a format that provides easy access for employees.

The Plant Superintendent ensures that all operators have the required training to properly and safely operate the chlorine process. All new employees must complete at least 8 hours of initial training, which consists of chlorine specific safety and health hazards, process operations, and emergency operations including shutdown. Each employee must also complete at least 4 hours of refresher training every three years. The refresher training covers a review of all topics presented i

n the initial training, as well as any changes to the chlorine process or equipment. Employees are observed in operation to ensure proficiency following the training sessions.

Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) are conducted to identify, evaluate, and control the risk associated with process hazards and chlorine release scenarios. The overall purpose is to prevent or minimize the effects of a release. The PHA is conducted on the entire chlorine system. The Plant Superintendent updates the PHA at least once every five years, or when a major change occurs in the process.

A chlorine gas leak to the atmosphere is the primary hazard associated with this process. The worst case scenario would be represented by the complete failure (rupture) of a one-ton cylinder outside of the chlorine room, releasing 2000 pounds of chlorine into the air. Using EPA's guidance criteria, this release is calculated to take place over 10 minutes. At a wind speed of 3.4 mph in an urban setting, the chlorine gas would travel 1.3 miles before the concentration drops below the toxic endpoint, the level at which chlorine gas is no longer a hazard to the public. Depending upon the wind direction, such a release could affect a large area of the city and surrounding area. The population within a 1.3 mile radius of the WTP is estimated to be 17,157 people. This was determined using the "MARPLOT" computer software developed by the USEPA office of emergency management and NOAA (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration).

Numerous alternate release scenarios were considered. The alternate release scenario chosen represents a more plausible possibility than the loss of a complete cylinder. This situation involves the failure or damage of a fusible plug on the chlorine tank. This would allow chlorine gas to escape uncontrolled from the valve for an estimated time of one hour. This type of release would occur within the chlorine room of the water plant, which would provide a reduction in the release rat

e to the atmosphere. Using EPA's guidance criteria, the total release would be 554 pounds. At a wind speed of 6.7 mph, the chlorine gas would travel less than 0.1 miles before the concentration drops below the toxic endpoint. Using the "MARPLOT" computer software calculation, the population within this 0.1 mile radius of the WTP is 85 people. Those possibly affected by such a release would be primarily the residents to the south and west of the WTP.

During the past five years, there have been no accidental releases of chlorine from the Wheeler Avenue WTP in which chlorine escaped offsite. Minor leaks have been noted within the chlorine room and were handled promptly. These type responses are incidental, and are not considered a response action. No threat was posed to the public or the environment.

In the event of an accidental release, the WTP emergency action plan contains the procedures for evacuation of the plant and immediate notification of the fire department. The fire department is responsible for control of the chlorine leak and evacuation of any affected residents. The fire department have copies of the WTP Chlorine Manual and risk management plan and have the necessary equipment to respond to these type emergencies.
